subject: meta-phytium: Add a new meta layer for Phytium Technology Co., Ltd
commitMessage:
meta-phytium: Add a new meta layer for Phytium Technology Co., Ltd

This commit adds the meta-phytium layer that includes configuration,
licens, maintainer and owners files for Phytium Technology Co., Ltd.

Signed-off-by: tianjingzai <tianjingzai@phytium.com.cn>
Change-Id: I344a39f7efd2f611c19f60d6753ccceacd02594d

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

User not approved, see admin, no CI
Excuse me, could you spare some time to review my submission? Thank you in advance.

what happened here? You gave about 20 minutes after submission before asking for review and then abandoned the commit entirely. Usually, unless there is a high priority, we don’t have a response time for review that fast. 

It looks like there isn’t a Jenkins group assigned for your company. Has there been a CCLA submitted?  This is necessary before we can accept code.
There were some typos in the submission, and a CCLA wasn't submitted. So the commit was withdrawn back. BTW, will both patches and merge requestes be accepted by openbmc project?

> There were some typos in the submission, and a CCLA wasn't submitted. So the commit was withdrawn back. 

Understood.  Alternatively you could have marked it WIP until the CCLA is submitted.

> BTW, will both patches and merge requestes be accepted by openbmc project?

I don't know what you mean by this question.  We generally only accept contributions via Gerrit, which is neither PRs or patches.

A very few repositories we maintain are forks of upstream repositories, such as openbmc/linux, and those follow their upstream process.  In the case of Linux kernel contributions they do go as patches to the openbmc mailing list.

If the repository is in Gerrit, use Gerrit.  If it is not in Gerrit but on openbmc's Github organization it probably uses the mailing list as patches.  See https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/9915e5d21d3009eab284b321fef46f9301a13206/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-changes

> > There were some typos in the submission, and a CCLA wasn't submitted. So the commit was withdrawn back. 
> 
> Understood.  Alternatively you could have marked it WIP until the CCLA is submitted.

Thank your reply. I am unable to access the CCLA link given by openbmc, could you send me a copy of the CCLA?
> 
> > BTW, will both patches and merge requestes be accepted by openbmc project?
> 
> I don't know what you mean by this question.  We generally only accept contributions via Gerrit, which is neither PRs or patches.

I am sorry for making you confusion. Merge request means that using the command "push gerrit HEAD:refs/for/master". I am not sure PRs is the same meanings with MRs(merge requestes). If they are different, this commit will be sent to openbmc repository in form of patches.
>  
> A very few repositories we maintain are forks of upstream repositories, such as openbmc/linux, and those follow their upstream process.  In the case of Linux kernel contributions they do go as patches to the openbmc mailing list.
> 
> If the repository is in Gerrit, use Gerrit.  If it is not in Gerrit but on openbmc's Github organization it probably uses the mailing list as patches.  See https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/9915e5d21d3009eab284b321fef46f9301a13206/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-changes

Thanks a lot.

> I am sorry for making you confusion. Merge request means that using the command "push gerrit HEAD:refs/for/master". I am not sure PRs is the same meanings with MRs(merge requestes). If they are different, this commit will be sent to openbmc repository in form of patches.

No problem.  Sometimes there is confusion with github process (pull request / merge request) and our [gerrit] process.  I was trying to be clear.

We do accept changes via Gerrit (as I elaborated on later).

> > I am sorry for making you confusion. Merge request means that using the command "push gerrit HEAD:refs/for/master". I am not sure PRs is the same meanings with MRs(merge requestes). If they are different, this commit will be sent to openbmc repository in form of patches.
> 
> No problem.  Sometimes there is confusion with github process (pull request / merge request) and our [gerrit] process.  I was trying to be clear.
> 
> We do accept changes via Gerrit (as I elaborated on later).

Get it,thank you clarity reply. A signed CCLA will be submitted as soon as possible, then the commit is  about to reopen after revision.
